To whom this English-for-Vietnamese letter does not get on his nerves,

Since last year, we have got someone to upload daily articles on Monster Boxâ€™s facebook page - whose popularity, in turn, has marginally soared from to 70,000 likes. Which, nonetheless, is by no means a handsome feat.

Fortunately enough, were statistical figures our ultimate goal, we must have given it up in poignant desperation. We must have been determined enough to stay breezeless of the foul-mouthed who, as a rule, always yelp â€œIâ€™d never delve into this long-drawn-out articleâ€ in either shared posts, or tagged comments. Our customers are you - those de facto slog through our articles. After all, the most lofty goal of ours is that our every post is puissant enough to urge readers to immediately tag someone, or to share it on their walls so that â€œsomeoneâ€ could enjoy it as much as they did.

(Or to win back the so-called â€œf*ck this long-drawn-out articleâ€).

That said, it still appears woefully common that even the most loyal Monster Box readers, given their every personal reason, â€œtiptoeâ€ the posts at times. Which is self-evident enough - as an inescapable, bitter truth.

After all, I know horribly well that our every reader has his/her own life, and that at the end of the day, to splurge his/her meagre levels of energy and attention on wordy Monster Box writings must sound somewhat extravagant. This society, at its core, is pre-designed as to cast our remaining â€œbatteryâ€ on light entertainment, and some "no-brainer" things, instead of some tense, stressful, and concentration-demanded s-h-i-t-storms.

Even if the excitement, alongside the hunger for knowledge can somehow urge us to squander some time each night on Monster Box, there is still every other thing to r-e-t-a-r-d our should-have-been intimate fellowships.

On the one hand, time distorts our first-day impressions. Everything is, simply enough, getting day-over-day more tenuous, given our every resisting attempt. Ice melts, and the bedroom becomes woefully cluttered, and we, by the same token, are getting turned off by each other. This, nevertheless, is woefully common as though we just wake up feeling a bit less enamored of Monster Box than we did the day before. For then, our personal lives undergo constant changes, thus, attention needs redirecting onto more pivotal/intimate things such as new jobs, crushes, or friends, instead of some eccentric Facebook page.

This is sad, yeah I know, but it is how nature de facto works.

Apart from the fact that some natural forces that indeed wear down our impressions on certain entities, there is every other to assure that the mutual contempt is inescapable.

Many, for example, fall head over heels for Monster Box - the very page that composes the article "implying what I mean, so vividly, honestly and systematically demonstrating the troubles I have oftentimes run into". This way, nothing could possibly guarantee their playing Judas against those thereby championing arguments against theirs. Which has de facto happened as though it were perennial - given our human nature: doting on whatever for, whilst despising things against our will. A such human mentality has subsisted since the dawn of TV  (skip every â€œunappealingâ€ channel), newspapers (eschew the â€œdrabâ€ newspapers), and eventually social platforms (swat at dreary online opinions).

Thus, as a rule, the human contempt is raging, especially on social networks. The â€œraid bossâ€, after all, is that it evokes some sense of "betrayal" seeing our â€œall-time sweetheartsâ€ propagating what we loathe. Every so often, such a grudge may get even more severe than our every former contempt.

Among our 300 articles amidst this time, some refer to the rightist view, while others fuel leftism. At times, we also unintentionally fell for prejudices. Consequently, some rightists sparked a rumor that "Monster Box is the speaker of the left", whilst the young leftists did fiercely bellyache "Monster Box propagates the pure, far-right ideologies".

Given a such feat, mistakes must be woefully common. Also, we know woefully well that we are often scrutinized by masterminds of certain fields, for example, anime culture, quantum physics, and so forth. Even though these Brobdingangians oftentimes adore Monster Boxâ€™s articles on fields other than their majors, when it comes to their strengths, every technical mistake may easily get on their nerves. At times, such extremes puff up their egos - and all an inflated ego ever hurts for is to prove their supremacy.

The evoked contempt, thus, is inevitable.

What seems critical, on the other hand, is that were Monster Box to home in the so-called â€œtranquilityâ€, thus never  laying hands on contentious topics - perhaps we would end up drearily dull and woefully more ill-favored. Nor could this revelation ever roll in.

That said, such an aversion can be effortlessly addressed, as long as we are all open to each other. By no means does that openness implies blind obedience - it rules that given our disagreement, still we hold dear to each other, refraining our egos for something more elegant than ours.

On the other hand, seldom is this a one-sided contempt - Monster Box actually disgusts its readers at times. Withal our grief of the time-washed loyalty, we are often distressed at some former supportersâ€™ foul-mouths, or every reason to sell us out.

After all, we are all dogged by that very law - that we would end up loathing each other.

At first, rarely could I enjoy these so-called â€œconfession seriesâ€ (de facto Lam and Liemâ€™s suggestion). Little by little, I, however, have doted on the very playground, on which we, together with readers, can converse like adults. At times, I do disgust you as much - which evidences that every Monster Box employee is no less â€œhumanâ€ than you.  We also own as little as 24 hours, abear every human emotion, bite our nails at every daily lifeâ€™s problem, and are ultimately humans. We are, thus, by no means something virtual, or some latent beings without any civil rights.

Nevertheless, people often overpass a such self-evident fact. Many gravitate towards idealizing seemingly noble things, wiring â€œdivinityâ€ on celebrities as if they were flawless, hollow creatures.

To put into perspective, given my seniority in the media-advertising sector, your must-have-been-saintlike idols hold even more flaws than you, the ordinary fans. Which is, I reckon, a norm - unless they do, that would be eccentric. At the very core, this sector aims at puffing things up, selling you those puffed up expectations to somehow escape your dull reality.

Should you conjecture your expectations constitute your reality - prepare to savor the incoming poignancy.

After all, the readerâ€™s idealization is woefully hazardous, even though it at times is conducive to the community. For example, 4 spelling mistakes in a 4,000-word post still is so unbearable that readers are often fouled up by which. A "real" translator, by the same token, would never misinterpret any sentence in any however-thick-book. So is every Monster Boxâ€™s word, which must be as incontrovertibly true as that of the Central Propaganda Department.

Given that we also make every effort to fuel such expectations, this life is still so woefully convoluted that we, painstakingly enough, have oftentimes run ourselves into mistakes. Noticing such flaws, your very responsibility is to gently report and help do away with which, instead of triumphally howling as though you have just destroyed some villains, and should be knighted soon enough.

"Go through the given problem", replied I to a reader, who in turn yelped, "How could you articulate such a heinous statement, ainâ€™t it ad hominem?â€

We are here to respect each other, but this does not mean, nor does it ever mean, that we must serve and pamper any audience.

(We, akin to you, also long for such a human thing).

There is another thing that bothers me, that things are somehow unequal in the first place. For example, 10 goods amount to 1 bad. Like writing 10 good and good articles in a row is obvious and "should have been" in the eyes of everyone, but one â€œbadâ€ post is enough to make the impression enough to ruin almost everything. You may feel "normal" when ten Monster Box fuel your wills, yet one against is enough to evoke "eh, these guys suck, let us rub them offâ€.

Every so often, I still come across every malicious comment (not in Monster Box) on "gifted school" or " the deceptive astrology article". They, after all, rarely heed the falsifiability of which. What matters is that they see these posts as the representatives, the emblems, the "real Monster Boxâ€, even though both account for some 0.4% of what we have ever written.

This very formula, however, puts things more at risk than ever: there is every life lesson to evidence that one misstep only can cost you every former goodness. That said, seldom do I gnaw at which, for negativity is constituted of more than purely some â€œserendipityâ€ - which, I reckon, can be quelled by our human seriousness and concentration.

So, given my confession that not every Monster Box article is of equal quality (which is woefully common), my very belief is that the seemingly disappointing never amounts to as much as 5%. We are striving for a better rate in the future, as we always are. The publication frequency, for example, has lately been loosened to assure higher quality, even though this could put us at algorithmic risks.

We, however, seldom take to Facebook, nor Mark's lame algorithms - after all, Monster Box aims at "growing" alongside its readers. Our best bet is that our regular readers have savored significant cognitive-knowledge maturity. And it sounds auspicious enough.

Thank you for granting Monster Box, along with yourselves, an invaluable mutual-growth opportunity. We all deserve our future, better selves. Having all too often encouraged Monster Box to put every effort in a brighter future, now let us spare a bit for yourselves as well.

Bear in mind that you deserve more - as always - and one of that â€œmoreâ€ is Monster Box's existence.

Stay heedful of which.
